text.p: Russian Dmitry Sautin, Europe's best men's diver, took an assured victory in the European championship three-metre springboard event on Saturday.
Olympic highboard champion Sautin, 21, retained the title he won in Vienna two years ago with by a margin of more than 50 points over his nearest rival.
Diving with consistency far beyond the rest of the 11-man field, he won the gold medal with 661.68 points after carrying over 234.72 points from his five dives in the semifinal.
Germans Andreas Wels, the winner of the one-metre event on Thursday, and Stefan Ahrens duelled for the silver medal.
Wels took it on the penultimate of his six dives and did not falter with his final effort to score 609.39 points.
However the day belonged to Sautin.
"It was more difficult when I won in Vienna. There the rivals were more dangerous," Sautin said.
"I was absolutely confident I was going to take the gold. In fact I thought I would take the gold since the beginning of the season."
Sautin's optimism stemmed from the fact that he was diving pain-free in a major international event for the first time in more than two years.
He injured his left wrist badly during a competition in February 1995 but only had an operation after the Atlanta Olympics.
"Now it's a pleasure to dive once more," Sautin smiled.
His highlight was a reverse 3-1/2 somersault dive.
Only two other divers attempted one with such great difficulty but neither came close to Sautin's achievement.
The competition was delayed several times by faults with the electronic scoreboard but the Russian said he did not even notice.
"I was concentrating so hard," Sautin said.
Russia also won the other final on the fourth day of the championships to take their tally to six out of eight gold medals awarded so far.
The synchronised swimming duo of Olga Brusnikina and Maria Kiseleva performing to themes from famous Western films and won with 99.16 points including three perfect 10s for artistic interpretation.
France took the silver medals with 97.04 points while Italy were third with 95.76 points.
